frontMatter.title: ST-1: The boy and the buffalo
frontMatter.author: Halbi Text typed in Devanagari script by Durga, c1974. Researcher: Fran Woods

textInfo.textTitle: ST-1: The boy and the buffalo

interlinear.free: There was an old man.
He had one son.
The old man cares for his son by making plows.
One day he went to the jungle.
And he made three or four (plows).
And having carried (on his shoulder) he got tired.
And he is saying.

"Come, friend, kiɽa makɽa sap ɖʰẽɖu, carry these for me.
The reference to kiɽa makɽa sap ɖʰẽɖu is unclear.
I will give you my only son (in marriage)," (so) saying he called out two or three times.
Then, at whatever place it is, the Raksin spirit was there.
And it heard (the old man).
And it came.
And it carried (the plows).
Then the old man said.
"Stay here by the pond. I will send (my son)," he said.
And he went to his house.
And he said to his son.
"Go bathe, Babu," he said.
Then the boy said, "Okay."
And he was going.
And on the way was sona rupa boela (buffalo).
And it asked the boy.
"Where are you going, Babu?" it said.
Then the boy said.
"I am going to bathe, " he said.
Then the buffalo said.
"Don't go! Your father has made a vow to a Raksin spirit," it said.
And it told the boy.
And it said.

"Take hold of (these) bullet-like thorns, bullet-like fire, and bullet-like water (and) run!
Meaning of the items listed is not known though their purpose and function are.
When arrive near (the river) release (these) one by one'" it said.
And how they ran!
How they ran!
The Raksin spirit is also chasing (them).
When they arrive the buffalo says.
"Release the bullet-like fire," it (the buffalo) says.
Then the boy released the bullet-like fire.
Then there was a fire everywhere.
(Raksin) took no notice whatsoever of it!
It is just chasing (them).
Then, "Release the bullet-like thorns," (the buffalo) said.
Then he released the bullet-like thorns.
Then on the path the Raksin spirit was running on, thorns covered the area.
It also paid absolutely no attention (to the thorns).
It is just chasing (them).
They are running.
They are running.
It is just chasing them.
Then, "release the bullet-like water," (the buffalo) said.
Then (the boy) released the bullet-like water.
Then it (Raksin) tripped over into the lake.
Later, (Raksin spirit) could not cross over that water.
They (the boy and the buffalo) are on that side (of the lake).
Like that they are being there however many days it is, they are there on the bank of the lake.
At that place the water spirits say to the boy.
"Hey foreigner, come play hide and seek," they say.
Then the boy told the buffalo.
"Older brother, some lovely girls come here to play.
And they also tell me to come play (with them)," he said.
And he asked the buffalo.
"Where will they hide?" he said.
Then the buffalo told (him).
They will hide beneath the puran pan bush.
You (should) grab their uncut topknots," (the buffalo) said.
Then the boy said.
"Where will I hide?" he said.
Then the buffalo said.
"When it's your time to hide I will come to drink water.
At that time, hide inside my stomach," (the buffalo) said.
Then the boy said, "Okay."
Later, at the time of calling for him, he went.
They played.
They hid beneath the puran pan bush.
He grabbed the uncut topknots and lifted them up.
Later it became his turn.
Then he hid.
At that time the buffalo came to drink water.
Then (the boy) hid in its stomach.
They searched and searched and grew tired.
They absolutely did not find (him).
Later the water spirits said.
"Reveal yourself! We will give you one of our sisters (in marraige)," they said.
Then the boy quickly floated up to the surface of the stream.
Then the buffalo said to the boy.
"There are seven (sisters).
Take hold of the youngest one's hand.
Don't take hold of the older (sisters') hands.

Saying, "he is brother-in-law" having hit (with) fist they will be killed.
Meaning of muʈka muʈka marun morade unclear.
When (you) take hold of the younger one's hand saying "he is (your) brother-in-law" (then) no one touches (you)," it said.
Then the boy took hold of the youngest one's hand.
Then, saying, "he is brother-in-law" no one touches (him).
Later the boy took her to his house.
And they are there.
With that she quickly grew.
She became a young woman.
She became absolutely beautiful.
They were living there a very long time.

With that, in that city, saying "there is a war among the foreigners," they spread the news abroad.
Meaning not very clear.
And they sent letters far and wide.
The buffalo told the boy.
"Look, Babu, when I die, don't give (my body) for (their) taking" it said.
"You bring (it) and bury it separately," it said.
And (the buffalo) told the boy.
And it went itself to the war zone.
At that place it is the Kera Kam war.
The war happened.
They hit the buffalo (and) it died.
At the time of (the buffalo) dying, the boy brought it.
And he buried separately the horns, the eyes, (and) the tail.
From them, from the eyes became the two dogs, sõora and bʰõora.
The tail became a big stick.
The horns became metal sticks.
With this much, the story is finished.
